abstract.p: Letter by Seton Hall University dean W King Mott Jr on campus diversity; quotes one student who believed Mott wanted to fail her, because she had been told so by her advisers in unit for disadvantaged students (S)

block.p: I have witnessed Arthur Levine's observation regarding the segregated conditions at institutions of higher education (Op-Ed, June 11). Paradoxically, this is happening as increasingly diverse populations enter.

Just last September, while I was instructing a class, one student felt ''safe'' enough to describe how she was a target for failure. I asked her what she meant by that. She replied, ''I know that you want to fail me . . . everybody here wants me to fail.'' Amazed by her comments and her honesty, I asked where she had come to know this. ''My advisers (a unit in the university for economically disadvantaged students) told me.''

I have witnessed Arthur Levine's observation regarding the segregated conditions at institutions of higher education (Op-Ed, June 11). Paradoxically, this is happening as increasingly diverse populations enter.

Just last September, while I was instructing a class, one student felt ''safe'' enough to describe how she was a target for failure. I asked her what she meant by that. ''My advisers (a unit in the university for economically disadvantaged students) told me.''
This experience is unique only because it became part of a public conversation. Privately, enclaves of culture are at war with one another.
W. KING MOTT JR. Dean of Freshman Studies Seton Hall University South Orange, N.J., June 12, 2000
